dtc.name: Disability Tax Credit (DTC)
dtc.description: Non-refundable tax credit that reduces income tax for people with severe and prolonged impairments in physical or mental functions.

estimatedRefund.note: Depends on income history, years eligible, and whether you qualify for the supplement

eligibility.requirement: You must have a severe and prolonged impairment in physical or mental functions that markedly restricts your ability to perform a basic activity of daily living OR you need life-sustaining therapy.
eligibility.duration: Impairment must have lasted or be expected to last for a continuous period of at least 12 months.

categories.label: Vision
categories.description: You are blind or have significant visual impairment even with corrective lenses

categories.label: Speaking
categories.description: You are unable or take an extremely long time to speak so as to be understood in a quiet setting

categories.label: Hearing
categories.description: You are unable or take an extremely long time to hear so as to understand someone in a quiet setting

categories.label: Walking
categories.description: You are unable or take an extremely long time to walk even with appropriate therapy, medication, or devices

categories.label: Eliminating (Bowel/Bladder)
categories.description: You are unable or take an extremely long time to manage bowel or bladder functions

categories.label: Feeding
categories.description: You are unable or take an extremely long time to feed yourself even with appropriate therapy or devices

categories.label: Dressing
categories.description: You are unable or take an extremely long time to dress yourself even with appropriate therapy or devices

categories.label: Mental Functions (Memory, Problem Solving, Judgment, Adaptive Functioning)
categories.description: You are unable or take an extremely long time to perform mental functions necessary for everyday life (includes autism, ADHD, intellectual disabilities, brain injuries)

categories.label: Life-Sustaining Therapy
categories.description: You need therapy at least 3 times per week, for at least 14 hours per week (includes dialysis, chest physiotherapy, insulin therapy)

categories.label: Cumulative Effect of Significant Restrictions
categories.description: You have 2+ significant restrictions that together are equivalent to a marked restriction (e.g. difficulty with both dressing AND mental functions)

mentalFunctions.note: This is the most relevant category for autism/ADHD diagnoses
criteria: Adaptive functioning - difficulty with daily routines, self-care, social interactions
Memory - significant difficulty remembering things needed for daily life
Problem solving and goal setting - difficulty planning, initiating, or completing tasks
Judgment - difficulty making safe and appropriate decisions
Processing speed - takes significantly longer to understand and respond
autismSpecific: Difficulty with social communication and interaction
Restricted/repetitive patterns of behavior, interests, or activities
Sensory processing difficulties that impact daily functioning
Need for routine and difficulty adapting to changes
Difficulty with employment or maintaining employment
Need for significant support in daily living activities
commonMistakes: Describing what you CAN do instead of what you struggle with
Not mentioning how long activities take compared to others
Forgetting to mention the need for supervision or prompting
Not linking the impairment to specific daily activities
Doctor using too-clinical language instead of functional descriptions

steps.title: Get Diagnosed
steps.description: You need a formal diagnosis from a qualified medical practitioner. For autism, this is typically a psychologist or psychiatrist.
tips: If diagnosed as an adult, the diagnosis date matters for retroactive claims

steps.title: Find a Doctor to Complete T2201
steps.description: A medical practitioner must complete Part B of the T2201 form. This can be your family doctor, specialist, psychologist, or other qualified practitioner.
tips: Not all doctors are familiar with DTC - some may refuse
Bring your diagnosis report and a summary of your daily limitations
A psychologist who diagnosed you is often the best person to fill it out
Some doctors charge a fee ($50-200) for completing the form

steps.title: Complete Part A (Your Part)
steps.description: Fill out your personal information and identify which categories of impairment apply to you.
tips: Be thorough - list everything that applies

steps.title: Doctor Completes Part B
steps.description: Your medical practitioner describes your impairment, its effects on daily living, and certifies that it is severe and prolonged.
tips: The doctor should focus on what you CANNOT do or struggle with significantly
Use functional language, not just diagnostic labels
Note if the impairment existed before the diagnosis date

steps.title: Submit to CRA
steps.description: Mail or submit the completed T2201 to the CRA. Wait for their decision (typically 2-8 weeks).
tips: Submit digitally through My Account if possible

steps.title: If Approved - File Amended Returns
steps.description: Once approved, you can request adjustments to previous tax returns to claim the DTC retroactively.
tips: Use T1-ADJ or ReFILE to adjust previous years
You can go back up to 10 years
Consider hiring a tax professional for the amendments
The CRA will calculate and send you any refund owing

partA.categories: Check all that apply from the eligibility categories

partB.effects: Describe the effects on daily living
partB.duration: When did the impairment begin? Is it expected to last 12+ months?
partB.certification: Practitioner certifies the impairment is severe and prolonged

pwd.name: Persons with Disabilities (PWD) Designation
pwd.description: Provincial designation that provides higher income assistance rates ($1,358.50/mo vs $935/mo) and additional benefits.

requirements: Have a severe mental or physical impairment
Impairment expected to continue for at least 2 years
Impairment directly and significantly restricts daily living activities
Need help or assistive devices for daily living

steps.title: Apply for Income Assistance First
steps.description: You must be receiving income assistance (welfare) before you can apply for PWD.

steps.title: Request PWD Application
steps.description: Ask your Employment and Assistance Worker for the PWD application package.

steps.title: Complete the Application
steps.description: Three parts: Self-Report, Assessor Report (doctor), and Activities of Daily Living report.

steps.title: Submit and Wait
steps.description: Submit to your worker. Decision typically takes 4-8 weeks.

screenerQuestions.question: Do you have a diagnosed medical condition or disability?
screenerQuestions.helpText: This includes physical disabilities, mental health conditions, neurodevelopmental conditions (autism, ADHD), chronic illnesses, etc.

screenerQuestions.question: What type of condition(s) do you have?
Has your condition lasted (or is expected to last) at least 12 months?
screenerQuestions.helpText: The DTC requires a 'prolonged' impairment lasting at least 12 continuous months.

screenerQuestions.question: What province do you live in?
Does your condition significantly affect your ability to perform daily activities compared to someone your age without the condition?
screenerQuestions.helpText: Think about things like: getting dressed, preparing meals, managing finances, navigating social situations, keeping a routine, maintaining employment.

screenerQuestions.question: Which daily activities are significantly affected? (Select all that apply)
Do daily activities take you significantly longer than someone without your condition?

options.label: Almost always takes extremely long or I cannot do them at all

screenerQuestions.question: Do you need help, supervision, or prompting from another person to complete daily activities?

options.label: Almost always need someone to help or prompt me

screenerQuestions.question: Have you filed Canadian tax returns in the past 10 years?
screenerQuestions.helpText: You need to have filed taxes to receive a DTC refund. If you haven't filed, you can still file late.

screenerQuestions.question: Have you had any taxable income (employment, EI, disability benefits, etc.) in the past 10 years?
screenerQuestions.helpText: Even small amounts of income can result in a refund through the DTC.

screenerQuestions.question: When were you first diagnosed with your condition?
Have you already applied for any of the following? (Select all that apply)
